title: Latest update 115.3.3. Can't enlarge 'displayed' message box to suitable size?
content:
Thunderbird decided to update itself to 115.3.3 (64-bit) today. Not pleased.

The main screen is basically divided in to three areas (boxes). On the left I have my different email accounts, lower down I have my folders for saved messages (1).

Top right is showing message headers (Subject, From, Recipient, Date etc.) (2).

Under the above box is more details of message header, then under that is the message 'body'.

I can easily change the vertical divider bar between the left box (1) and the two stacked boxes on the right (2), Good :)

However the horizontal divider between the top right box and the bottom right box has limited movement, so I'm unable to enlarge the message 'body' section (3) to be able to read more than a line or two. Also it would help if the top of section 3 where the From, To, Subject and Date are repeated from box 2 were removed (as I said, they're repeats of box 2) leaving more space for the message body contents.

I've found some settings for font size which helped a little, but how do I improve on what you can see in my image please?

I suspect I could change the screen resolution, but with my poor eye sight, how do I read the text in other programs?

Thanks in advance

title: Deleting bottom  lines from email list - thunderbird v115
content:
My Thunderbird was upgraded automatically and I got v115. A previous upgrade switched my upgrade settings so... Anyway, I solved a couple of annoying issues so I am not unhappy. I have the view set up as "Classic View"; it's too bad every time I change a view setting the menu disappears instead of staying open so I can test the view to see what it looks like instead of having to navigate back to the view again. When the number of lines in the email listing exceeds the displayed area, and I navigate to the last item, which moves everything up so the last item is the last line in the current email listing pane, then delete that last line the lines rearrange themselves (not sort order) so the new last line is below the pane and I have to scroll down again to see the new last email line (even though the new last line is highlighted it cannot be seen in the email list pane). The pane should rearrange so the last line is the last line displayed so I can press the [Del] key multiple times to delete the multiple junk email starting with the last line and see everything happening instead of hoping it happens.

Is there a fix for this? Thanks,
creator: BPaul_H

title: keyboard shortcuts
content:
I am an old IT guy, have used email for many years, from character terminals to pc to smartphone. I have used Thunderbird for many years, and I actively promote it to many people, including non-IT people. I understand why keyboard shortcuts exist, but it is very confusing to explain unintended behaviours caused simply by the user's cursor being at the wrong place. I am very careful myself, but I also have had to search the ends of the earth to find inadvertently deleted/archived/threaded messages.

Particularly if Thunderbird wishes to remain relevant in the future, which means relevant to younger folk who, unlike us, did not grow up on character-based applications, it's time to move to the future and ditch most of the keyboard shortcuts, or at least to include a configuration option to change or disable most of them, most urgently the single-letter shortcuts, which can easily be triggered inadvertently.

I'm sure some long term users would object strenuously to getting rid totally, so let it be a config option. The fact that the message boards are not full of complaints does not mean people are not annoyed, just accepting of this annoyance because otherwise Thunderbird is so much better than any other client!
creator: bags

TIA.

title: Timestamp in contact email addresses imported into Thunderbird.
content:
Hi,

I think this is an error in the contact import routines for Thunderbird. Yesterday I imported several email accounts into a newly installed version of Thunderbird. A couple of them were new with little or no history, but one had been in use for a long time, so I clicked the options to import contacts and known mail addresses. I now see a number of addresses with ~TimeStamp1697730047279 in them in the contacts list within Thunderbird. Actually, constant part is ~TimeStamp169, followed by another 9 digits. I believe this comes consistently before the @ symbol, introducing the mail domain. To me, this looks like a mistake when importing a symbol, but I have no idea a what stage of the import it would arise.

I'm actually quite new to Thunderbird. Is this sort of thing common or have I possibly missed out something in setting up the profile? The account details originally came from BT mail. As you may know, that was originally based on Yahoo, but now they have their own BT web mail tool. So, I suppose Thunderbird may have applied templates designed for Yahoo, and then found an incomplete match.

So far, I've been quite impressed with Thunderbird, in particular the power of what you can apparently do. I'm experimenting with whether I can use this mail tool more generally, but I have to be convinced that I can operate it cleanly.

I guess that's a long introduction. What I really want to know now is 2 questions:

  1. What can I do now to fix this problem, or contamination of the data.
  2. What can I do more generally to avoid behaviour of this kind in the future.

Many thanks, for any help or pointers on this topic.

Cheers,

C. J.
creator: cj_rupp

title: Thunderbird on OS X version 10.15.7 Catalina suddenly began always crashing; Crash ID: bp-290856b9-84d7-4075-aada-dfe180231020
content:
Crash ID: bp-290856b9-84d7-4075-aada-dfe180231020

The Thunderbird icon changed to a "generic icon" as seen both in the Applications folder and on the OSX Doc, seems just when Thunderbird began crashing.

My iMac was running very low on disk space, less than 400 MB, possibly as low as 100 MB, even while Thunderbird was downloading mail headers and messages, catching up on mail since the past few days.

I tried freeing up disk space while Thunderbird was doing this. Finally, it seemed after 30-60 minutes that Thunderbird had downloaded/retrieved all outstanding mail. Everything seemed OK, no apparent problems, except it seemed some messages hadn't been moved from Inbox to destination local folders.

I don't think I've ever done this before, I chose to have Thunderbird apply "all" message rules to the Inbox. I walked away for an hour or so. Later I returned and all seemed well. That is, all messages seemed processed by the rules, moved from Inbox to destination folders.

I was using Thunderbird just fine afterwards when suddenly it crashed. It has not run again despite multiple attempts to run Thunderbird. It crashes every time. Help please.

title: Can not write to e-mail box, cannot filter to folder
content:
I have been getting seemingly random failures to download e-mail from gmail.com I am currently running 115.3.3 64bit, but the problem started with a previous 32 bit version.

Other research suggested that the 32bit versions had a hardcoded limit of 4gigabytes per account, and that the 64bit version had no such limit. The account in question takes up approximately 1.64gbytes, with the two largest folders at 249mbytes and 216mbytes.

It was also suggested that Local Folders was not subject to the 4gbyte limit. I moved a few of the largest folders to Local Folders; that was no help with the cannot write mailbox problem, cannot filter to folder problem and the cannot move messages to folder problem.

I compact folders regularly, the problems return.

NTFS version 3.1 OS Name Microsoft Windows 10 Pro 64-bit operating system, x64-based processor Version 10.0.19045 Build 19045 Installed Physical Memory (RAM) 8.00 GB Total Physical Memory 7.74 GB Available Physical Memory 1.95 GB Total Virtual Memory 10.7 GB Available Virtual Memory 2.83 GB Page File Space 2.98 GB

Incidently, I have a Windows7 system that recently upgraded itself to Thunderbird 115. I have not experienced these sorts of problems there (yet)

Thanks for any help that can be given.
